1092511248829243392.text: 9/ What if we modify our mental model to “change is the default”, how can we thrive in ebbs and flows, with a retraining mindset, and a hunger to adapt and overcome (a standard part of any military basic training)? IMO how we think is our biggest obstacle, or strength.

1092511248246235137.text: 8 / I like Nick’s policy reco but suggest a twist. Unpopular opinion: Job instability is feature, not a bug. We got ourselves into this mess on assumption that future would look like the past. Through different lens, instability could be innovation, stability could be stagnation.

1092511247642193920.text: 7/ Nick proposes an innovative set of labor policies. Fully portable accrued benefits (vacay, health, 401k), following the worker from job to job, or contract to contract which could lead to greater quality of life for those affected.

1092511247004622848.text: 6/ Caused by a trillion-dollar-a-year transfer of wealth from wages to corporate profits, and structural changes to how we work, i.e. more or less the gig economy “you’re on your own,” benefit-free, race-to-the-bottom reality for millions of American workers.

1092511246375575553.text: 5/ Captains of industry and their congressional surrogates seek government certainty on regulations, taxes, and energy which have increasingly improved the last decade, but this certainty isn’t manifesting for the middle class in demand and discretionary spending

1092511245759012864.text: 4/ The new era: economy of work but not “jobs”, much flexibility with time, but few benefits, stability and security. Missing a labor ownership framework, arguably because innovation outpaced thinking/planning.

1092511245096280065.text: 3/ Our parents era: hard work rewarded with good pay, improving prospects, and comfy retirement, maybe work for only a couple of companies over lifetime – never more than one at a time.

1080626610242347009.text: 37/75 But change is afoot, @lwsnbaker highlights the coming change in User/Worker power.https://twitter.com/lwsnbaker/status/1052291645884882944 …

1080626609537802240.text: 36/75  “The way our digital economy is structured today, none of the members of the crowd who created this value actually capture any of it; instead, all of that value flows into the hands of just a few people who built the platform.” @BradRiewhttps://medium.com/@riew.brad/could-data-markets-generate-a-universal-basic-income-c4b6981afc79 …

1080625321597005824.text: 35/75 @Glenweyl & Posner’s Radical Markets +Lanier’s earlier work, “Facebook, for example, pays out only about 1% of its value each year to workers (programmers) because it gets the rest of its work for free from us! In contrast, Walmart pays out 40% of its value in wages."pic.twitter.com/N4CXFDH9Sw

1080625320493891584.text: 34/75 Make no mistake, the hours you spend online you are training their AI, performing very valuable work, enabling Facebook and Google to monopolize their industries and crush suppliers profitability. YOU are an unpaid data laborer.

1080625319734796288.text: 33/75 In Lanier’s Who Owns The Future? He highlights Instagram was not worth a billion dollars just because those thirteen employees were extraordinary. Instead the value came from the millions of users who contribute to the network without being paid for it.

1080625318992310273.text: 32/75 For example… Up till now your data (attributes, behaviors and location i.e. “the product”) have been treated as capital by companies like Facebook and Google, enabling their outsized profits to benefit a few owners, while never ending the opaque exploitation of YOU.

1080625317297893376.text: 31/75 Tokenized unions would not be just for workers, but could also assist social media boycotts, bank customers, pharma patients, political party organizations and even medical research, all without commuting or hiring childcare for busy parents

1080625315494260736.text: 30/75 My belief is that over time unions will not be external organizations (as it were in the past) but instead will be native to ANY organization as we reduce friction in connecting these networks.https://twitter.com/ElephasVentures/status/1055200142024835073 …

1080625314567352320.text: 29/75 To further expound on @OneAdamReese & @Vitolae-- using a blockchain could improve transparency and reduce friction for unions, in  collective bargaining, insurance, collecting dues, fundraising, voting, compliance audits, complaints, legal aid and other services.

1080625312843542528.text: 28/75 .@Vitolae shares “...Blockchain technology have the potential to transform the world of work profoundly, improve how labour markets work, increase transparency and equality, empower smaller parties”https://medium.com/willbe-group/why-the-blockchain-could-mean-so-much-for-the-future-of-work-f92bc7ce26a6 …

1080625311820144640.text: 27/75 @OneAdamReese proposes DAO union that “...seeks to safeguard the rights of various classes of people... for whom unionization has been impractical or impossible up to this point.”https://www.ethnews.com/the-decentralized-union-a-blockchain-use-case …

1080625311086067712.text: 26/75 UCLA Professor @rameshmedia encourages readers to imagine a world in which sharing/ gig economy apps "could work with labor unions … rather than relying on flexible contract labor without benefits or insurance."

1080624656686604288.text: 25/75 VC @NickHanauer: “An economy based on micro-employment requires the accrual of micro-benefits” and proposes a Shared Security Account that includes benefits proration, portability and universality.”https://democracyjournal.org/magazine/37/shared-security-shared-growth/ …

1080624655474384896.text: 24/75 Staff Writer @AlanaSemuels homes in on why this new way of making money falls short of the standard job: health care, primarily, but also a lack of paid sick leave and worker’s compensation.https://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2017/11/gig-economy/544895/ …

1080624653117284353.text: 23/75 Let’s talk about the gig economy: it’s already big (25%+ of American workers) and growing fast, provides workers time/role flexibility and corporations a flexible/agile talent pool, BUT does not provide job benefits nor stability. For example…

1080624649157758976.text: 22/75 History lessons and policymaking aside, there are a number of innovations occurring now and on the horizon that can impact the future of work, in my view, to create another BILLION better jobs…

1080624645596798977.text: 21/75 US policymakers have addressed big gaps before, i.e. mandatory high school after the transition out of agriculture and the GI Bill after WWII. Both helped grow an affluent middle class.pic.twitter.com/22ZsFuXvbn

1080624644967751680.text: 20/75 Not all experts agree with Federico, but most everyone agrees that automation displacement, retraining and reemployment gaps are realistic wholesale threats to economies around the world

1080624644086935552.text: 19/75 @FedericoPistono highlights: this technological revolution is replacing cognitive skills and moving much faster than past technologies, and that has never happened before. Also a disconnect between productivity (high) and wages (flat) and shallower recession recoveries.

1080624643252211712.text: 18/75 “THIS TIME IT’S DIFFERENT” says @FedericoPistono  as he explains why we will NOT create more jobs than we lose in the coming AI technological revolution. Check this video...https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u8wIXrFy1YY …

1080624642467876864.text: 17/75 The displacement and retraining transition is already underway at an Amazon warehouse in New Jersey, @nickwingfieldhttps://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/10/technology/amazon-robots-workers.html …

1080624641792663552.text: 16/75 ...BUT 400 to 800M individuals could be displaced by automation and need to find new jobs and may require retraining. Nonetheless a net gain.

1080624641125707776.text: 15/75 But some good news: @McKinsey_MGI estimates creation of 500 to 900M FTE jobs by 2030 from seven catalysts: rising incomes, aging health care, tech spending, real estate investment, infrastructure investment, energy transitions and efficiency.

1080624640349810688.text: 14/75 Tech-enabled automation as the culprit to income inequality, @erikbryn and @amcafee argue. New jobs benefit the educated, corp income with digital products (marginal cost) is going to owners not workers, and digital economy often benefits superstars over everyone else…

1080624638193917952.text: 13/75 But in the last 40 years, income inequality is accelerating. Data from @wid_inequality and @tegmark illustrate after the 1970’s, the bottom 90% income flattens while the top 10% take much more. And tech automation seems to be the culprit.pic.twitter.com/lmRd0Kln5k

1080624637220769792.text: 12/75  It’s a cycle. One new innovation leads to others that we usually cannot fathom ahead of time. In @tegmark’s Life 3.0 he asserts we invented fire, repeatedly messed up, then invented the fire extinguisher, fire exit, fire alarm and fire department.

1080624636365201408.text: 11/75 The logic of why automation leads to more work: Automation > increase productivity > lower-priced consumer goods > new consumer demand > producers require additional management (hiring).

1080624635702460416.text: 10/75 And after the introduction of the ATM in 1969, the # of bank tellers grew, responsibilities evolved, banking overall has only expanded with the exception of the slowdown due to the 2008 financial crisis. Automation led to more work.

1080624635043926017.text: 9/75 Historical data suggests strong argument for creating more jobs than lost: Ford Model T, due to the assembly line, cars produced per employee nearly tripled, headcount grew more than 10x, car prices cut in half, and more people bought cars. Automation led to more work…

1080624633475325952.text: 8/75 Working hours have also decreased, shorter work days and more paid time off @McKinsey_MGIpic.twitter.com/aOVRc69ib4

1080624630652559360.text: 7/75 In technological revolutions, some sectors decline, others gain, and the definition of work evolves. from @McKinsey_MGI, Jobs Lost, Jobs Gainedpic.twitter.com/4dqfxiTGRS

1080624629440438273.text: 6/75 Let’s start with a brief summary of western technological revolutions from @CarlotaPrzPerez.  Each has a mania, a turning point then a golden age prosperity.pic.twitter.com/83l6CXau8A

1080624628328886273.text: 5/75 There are smart people and truth on both sides and few agree on timelines (10, 100, 300 yrs?). I am on the side of the latter camp, creating many new better jobs. Remember, according to a few billionaires, humans are headed to Mars, so there is much more work yet unfathomed

1080624627460624384.text: 4/75 On the threat of AI, there are (at least) two camps. One side: AI will take most all jobs and we need welfare-like universal basic income and something else to do with our time. Other side: we will create many new jobs that are even better, and be even better off.

1080624626500136960.text: 3/75 The #TheFutureOfWork may be #DistributedWork, unconstrained by congested cities and antiquated ways of organizing, with entirely new frontiers we haven’t fully understood yet.

1080624625510342656.text: 2/75 In this thread we are going to touch on YOU as an unpaid data laborer, the threat of AI, gig economy x.0, blockchains, tokenized unions, work in new worlds starting with virtual and gaming, and Mars and beyond. A BILLION BETTER JOBS BY 2040.
